Project Description  The 500 kilometer (km) Bishkek–Torugart road is part of the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Corridor 1 linking 
the Kyrgyz Republic with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and 
other Central Asian countries. The Torugart post is a major border 
control and customs facility between the Kyrgyz Republic and the 
PRC.  The  road  condition  is  poor;  border-crossing  facilities  and 
procedures  are  outdated  and  inefficient,  and  they  obstruct 
international  traffic  and  trade.  Improved  road  and  customs 
infrastructure will remove the obstruction and open up this corridor 
for wider regional trade and economic cooperation. It will reduce 
travel and transit times from the current 3–4 days to 2 days.  
 
Improvement of the Bishkek–Torugart road will be implemented in 
three phases and includes (i) improving 488 km of the Bishkek–
Torugart road in the Kyrgyz Republic and the 20 km Bishkek bypass 
road,  (ii)  modernizing  infrastructure  and  facilities  at  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic–PRC  border  crossing  at  Torugart,  and  (iii)  policy  and 
institutional  support  in  the  road  subsector.  This  proposal  is  for 
Project 1 (the Project), the outputs of which are (i) an improved 39-
km road section from Km 400 to Km 439 of the Bishkek–Torugart 
road, (ii) modernized customs infrastructure at the Kyrgyz Republic–
PRC border crossing at Torugart, (iii) a transport sector master plan 
for 2010–2025, and (iv) a fully operational Bishkek–Torugart Road 
Corridor Management Department (BTRMCD). 
   
Rationale  Regional cooperation in Central Asia has centered on transport, 
energy, and trade facilitation for the last decade since the launch of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-sponsored CAREC Program in 
1997. This proposal supports transport and trade facilitation under 
CAREC.  Endorsed  under  the  CAREC  Transport  and  Trade

ii   
Facilitation Strategy, the Bishkek–Torugart road forms part of the 
CAREC Transport Corridor 1. It is the shortest road link from Kashi, 
a vibrant cultural and trade center in the PRC, to consumer markets 
in  the  northern  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Kazakhstan,  and  Russian 
Federation. As part of the Silk Road that linked ancient China to the 
Western world, it also represents an important historical heritage. 
 
Development of the transport sector is a priority of the Government 
of the Kyrgyz Republic (the Government), as reflected in its Country 
Development Strategy for 2007–2010. Substantial investments of 
about $350 million were made in the last decade to rehabilitate the 
country’s major road corridors. Along with these investments, the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  has  also  made  progress  in  reforming  transport 
sector operations. It adopted the Road Sector Development Strategy 
for 2007–2010, increased road financing, and plans to outsource and 
privatize road maintenance operations. Improvement of the Bishkek–
Torugart  road  is  a  priority  investment  project  included  in  the 
Government’s strategy. 
 
ADB is the lead partner in developing the transport sector in the 
Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  Project  is  included  in  the  Joint  Country 
Support  Strategy  for  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  (2007–2010).  It  will 
complement  ADB-led  investment  and  policy  dialogue  in  the 
country and complete a key transport corridor connecting Bishkek, 
the capital of the Kyrgyz Republic, to Kashi in the PRC. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  Project  will  contribute  to  reducing  transport  costs  and 
fostering regional trade and tourism between the Kyrgyz Republic 
and the PRC. The outcome is improved access to markets, social 
services, and tourist destinations.

Procurement  All procurement to be financed with the ADB grant will be carried 
out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time). Contracts estimated to cost in excess 
of $500,000 equivalent for goods and $1.0 million for civil works 
will be procured through international competitive bidding. Civil 
works for the road improvement component have been packaged 
into  one  contract  to  be  financed  by  ADB  following  ADB’s 
international competitive bidding procedures. Civil works for the 
customs infrastructure improvement (estimated to cost less than 
$1.0  million)  will  be  financed  by  the  Government  following  its 
procurement  procedures.  Customs  operations  and  control 
equipment (estimated at $1.0 million) will be procured through 
ADB’s  international  competitive  bidding  procedures.  The 
Government has been advised that before the commencement of 
any procurement activity under national competitive bidding, ADB 
and the Government will review the national public procurement 
law to ensure consistency with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines.

Consulting Services  Implementation  of  the  Project  will  require  the  services  of 
consulting firms for construction supervision, project monitoring 
and  evaluation,  and  preparation  of  subsequent  phases.  The 
Project will require input of a team of international (46 person-
months) and national (137 person-months) consultants, who will 
supervise  the  civil  works  and  provide  on-the-job  training  for 
counterpart staff. A simplified technical proposal with quality- and 
cost-based  selection  method  will  be  used  to  select  the 
consultants. In addition, the following advisory consulting services 
will  be  required:  (i)  23  person-months  of  international  and  35 
person-months of national consulting services for preparation of a 
transport  sector  master  plan,  and  (ii)  30  person-months  of 
international and 50 person-months of national consulting services 
for  institutional  support  to  BTRCMD.  Quality-  and  cost-based 
selection  with  a  simplified  technical  proposal  will  be  used  for 
selection of advisory consultants. The services of an independent 
audit firm will be required for financial audit of project accounts. 
The  firm  will  be  engaged  following  least-cost  selection 
procedures. All consulting services to be financed by ADB will 
follow  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). 
   
Project Benefits and  By  improving  the  Bishkek–Torugart  road,  the  Project  will 
Beneficiaries  substantially reduce the existing obstruction to trade and foster 
regional economic cooperation. The entire region will benefit from 
the  Project,  while  the  project  area  will  gain  through  economic 
development and increased access to markets and social services. 
Improving the project road will reduce transport costs, contribute to 
commercial  and  industrial  development,  develop  tourism,  and 
generate employment opportunities. The overall economic internal 
rate of return of the Project is 14.7%, and the net present value is 
about $37.8 million. The Project is expected to help boost trade 
between the Kyrgyz Republic and the PRC. The total volume of 
bilateral trade is expected to grow from 0.5 million tons in 2007 to 3 
million tons in 2015, of which the Kyrgyz Republic–PRC border at 
Torugart is expected to contribute more than half. 
 
The Project is not a targeted poverty intervention. Nevertheless, by 
stimulating economic development, it will have poverty reduction 
impact and benefits. While the Project aims to facilitate regional 
trade and thereby benefit major businesses and those involved in 
trade  and  commerce,  it  will  also  significantly  benefit  rural 
communities and especially rural poor. Specifically, the Project will 
indirectly benefit 2.3 million people living along the project road, 51% 
of whom are women dominant in intra- and inter-oblast (province) 
trade and commercial activities in the Kyrgyz Republic. Two of the 
three oblasts where the project road passes have poverty levels

v
below the national average of 46%. Extreme poverty in these two 
oblasts is almost double the national average of 13.5%. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Key  assumptions,  on  which  the  Project  design  is  based,  are  (i) 
continued political stability and strong economic performance in the 
Kyrgyz Republic; (ii) continued commitments of the governments of 
the Kyrgyz Republic and the PRC to regional cooperation and to 
completing improvement of  the Bishkek–Torugart road corridor; (iii) 
continued external assistance to the road subsector in the Kyrgyz 
Republic; and (iv) implementation of the cross-border agreement 
between the Kyrgyz Republic, PRC, and Tajikistan. The main project 
risks include (i) projected international traffic may not materialize, and 
(ii) cost overruns due to sharp escalation of prices for construction 
materials and labor. Given current economic development in the 
region  and  trends  in  trade  and  transport  turnover  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic,  it  is  anticipated  that  projected  traffic  levels  will  indeed 
materialize.  It  is  expected  that  the  economies  of  the  regional 
countries will grow at least at the same pace as currently, and growth 
is likely to accelerate further. Price escalation factors were adjusted 
for current trend in world prices for major construction inputs and 
incorporated into the cost estimates to minimize the risk of project 
cost overrun. Based on these assumptions and the likelihood of 
risks, the Project’s benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh its 
costs.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Kyrgyz Republic for the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 (Bishkek–Torugart Road) Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Regional  cooperation  in  Central  Asia  has  centered  on  transport,  energy,  and  trade 
facilitation  for  the  last  decade  since  the  launch  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-
sponsored  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program  in  1997.  This 
proposal supports transport and trade facilitation through improvement of the Bishkek–Torugart 
road and a major border control and customs facility between the Kyrgyz Republic and the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). The 500 kilometer (km) Bishkek–Torugart road is part of 
CAREC Transport Corridor 1, which is identified in the CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation 
Strategy.1 It is the shortest road link from Kashi, a vibrant cultural and trade center in the PRC, 
to consumer markets in the northern Kyrgyz Republic, Kazakhstan, and Russian Federation. As 
part of the Silk Road that linked ancient China to the Western world, it also represents an 
important historical heritage. 
 
3.  The road condition is poor and border-crossing facilities and procedures are outdated and 
inefficient, thus obstructing international traffic and trade. Improvement of the project road and 
customs infrastructure at Torugart will remove the obstruction and open up this corridor for wider 
regional trade and economic cooperation. It will reduce travel and transit times from the current 3–4 
days to 2 days. Feasibility and social studies were undertaken under ADB technical assistance 
(TA) projects. 2 The design and monitoring framework of the Project is in Appendix 1.   
  
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Regional Trade and the People's Republic of China as Trading Partner 
4.  Fueled by robust economic growth in Central Asia and the PRC, Central Asian countries 
have experienced increasing trade among themselves, and predominantly with the PRC. Trade 
volumes in Central Asian countries have more than doubled since 1999, with total freight 
turnover growing from 145 billion ton-kilometers (ton-km) in 1999 to about 300 billion ton-km in 
2006. The PRC has emerged as a major trading partner, with its share in the total imports of 
Central Asian countries3 exceeding 20% in 2006. A remarkable increase in trade with the PRC 
has  been  exhibited  by  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  (with  15-fold  growth  from  2001  to  2005)  and 
Tajikistan (with 20-fold growth in the same period). The PRC’s growing investments in Central 
Asia, particularly in the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan, will further boost trade. Once the project 
road and associated border infrastructure and procedures are improved, the road share of 
imports from the PRC will grow significantly and the proportion of exports will pick up gradually, 
especially once negotiated and potential mining and resource concessions to Chinese investors 
become operational in the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan.

trade) in 2002 to 540,147 tons (92% of total trade) in 2007.  More than half of the total trade

2.  Transport Sector Performance 
6.  Roads dominate the transport sector of the Kyrgyz Republic, accounting for about 94% 
of freight tonnage movements and almost all passenger traffic. The railway network consists of 
two separate branch lines, one linking the north of the country to the Kazakhstan’s rail system 
and another linking the south to Uzbekistan’s rail system, with no direct link between the two. Air 
transport accounts for less than 1% of passenger movements, and these are mainly between 
Bishkek and Osh. Water transport is confined to a few vessels on Lake Issyk-Kul. 
 
7.  The demand for transport has fallen dramatically since the country’s independence in 
1991. The lowest levels were reached in 1995, when the volume of freight in ton-km was only 
14% of its 1990 level and passenger movement was 33% of its 1990 level, reflecting a sharp 
decline in real incomes and output. In 2001, freight turnover (measured in ton-km) was only 
20% of its 1990 levels and passenger turnover was 57%. Demand grew steadily after 2001, with 
the railway’s share increasing from one third of the total freight turnover in 2001 to almost one 
half by 2006 (Table 2).

8.  Road Subsector. The 34,000 km road network in the Kyrgyz Republic evenly covers all 
seven oblasts, and provides connections to remote communities and neighboring countries. The

3 
Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) manages 18,810 km of republican roads, of 
which 22% are international roads, 30% are national, and 58% are rural. The remaining 15,910 km 
of roads are mainly rural roads under the jurisdiction of local governments. About 40% of the 
republican roads are paved, 50% are gravel, and the remaining 10% are dirt roads. 
 
9.  Due to a backlog in road maintenance and insufficient funding in the past two decades, the 
road network is estimated to have lost about $1 billion in road assets. Based on survey data of 
2005, two thirds of 4,300 km were in critical condition, and one fifth of the surveyed roads were so 
degraded that rehabilitation of the asphalt pavements was impossible. Only urgent action can 
prevent further degradation of the road infrastructure. Cognizant of this, the Government of the 
Kyrgyz Republic (the Government) has set improvement and maintenance of road infrastructure 
as one of its priorities and has embarked on a Road Sector Development Strategy for 2007–2010 
(RSDS),4 which proposes eight medium-term tasks with an objective of improving access to 
regional and local markets. These tasks are (i) rehabilitation and adequate maintenance, (ii) 
transport independence, (iii) improvement of the road financing system, (iv) involvement of the 
private sector in road construction and maintenance, (v) involvement of local communities in 
maintenance of local roads, (vi) institutional reforms, (vii) improvement of road safety, and (viii) 
use of modern technologies in road management and monitoring. RSDS also lists eight prioritized 
transport corridors in the Kyrgyz Republic, which include the Bishkek–Torugart road, with the 
target of improving 35% of the road up to international standards by 2010.  
 
10.  To implement the RSDS, the Government estimated that (i) investment of $490 million 
would be needed to rehabilitate the remaining two key regional corridors (i.e. the Bishkek–
Torugart road and Osh–Isfana road); and (ii) annual maintenance funding of $48 million would 
be required for MOTC administered roads. While funds for improvement of regional corridors 
will be sourced mainly from international financial institutions, financing road maintenance at the 
required level remains a challenge. However, the Government has made progress towards 
achieving the required level of financing. The total allocation for roads has increased 11-fold 
since 2000, and has tripled since 2005 (Table 3).

11.  The Road Fund enacted in 1998 has never truly functioned. Taxes are collected in the 
name of the Road Fund but are consolidated under the Government’s central budget. With the

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Constraints in the Transport Sector 
12.  Strategically  located  in  Central  Asia  and  given  the  fast-growing  economies  of  its 
neighbors (i.e. Kazakhstan and the PRC), the Kyrgyz Republic has potential to play a key role in 
bringing the external markets closer to Central Asia. Its transport infrastructure—constrained by 
the  country’s  landlocked  nature  and  mountainous  terrain—suffers  from  frequent  climatic 
calamities,  operates  inefficiently  with  substantial  maintenance  backlog,  and  faces  severe 
shortages in capital investment. At the same time, it is confronted with growing demand for 
regional  access  and  trade.  Key  challenges  that  the  Government  face  to  fully  realize  its 
aspirations of becoming a conduit for regional trade are (i) removing barriers to regional trade, 
(ii) building efficient and integrated transport systems, and (iii) catching up on the accumulated 
shortfall in sector financing and investment. As the country’s transport sector is dominated by 
road transport, these challenges are directly linked to the road subsector. An analysis of the 
road subsector in the Kyrgyz Republic is in Appendix 2. 
 
a.  Barriers to Regional Trade  
13.  Road conditions are poor and customs infrastructure and facilities at the Torugart border 
post do not comply with international standards, and need modernization. Border crossing is 
often delayed due to inadequate customs facilities and complicated procedures. Travelers are 
required to go through clearance at the border by several government agencies, including those 
responsible for border control, customs, sanitary, and transport. This results in the prolonged 
border crossing and travel time from Bishkek to Kashi takes up to 4 days. This situation 
constitutes a major barrier to regional trade. Improved roads and customs infrastructure, as well 
as  efficient  cross-border  procedures—such  as  a  single-window 6 service  and  automated 
clearance of border traffic— would help remove this barrier to ensure free flows of traffic and 
boost trade and commerce.

during the Fourth Ministerial Conference in Bishkek in 2005.7 The CAREC Transport and Trade 
Facilitation Strategy (footnote 1) calls for (i) establishing competitive transport corridors across 
the CAREC region; (ii) facilitating efficient movement through corridors and across borders; and

b.  Inefficient Transport Systems 
15.  Despite  the  recent  progress,  the  transport  system  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  remains 
inefficient mainly because of (i) weak strategies and regulations, (ii) inefficient planning and 
management, and (iii) limited institutional capacity.  
 
16.  Weak  Strategies  and  Regulations.  ADB  has  been  intensively  involved  in  policy 
dialogue with the Government in the past decade, and played an instrumental role in introducing 
market-based reforms in the transport sector and developing transport policy statements.9 While 
RSDS was the first step in defining the priorities to achieve road sector development, it largely 
remains a short-term output-oriented document with weak links to available financial resources. 
A comprehensive and coherent long-term strategic master plan is needed with emphasis on 
development of efficient and integrated transport systems.   
 
17.  Inefficient Planning and Management. Planning and management practices in the 
transport sector remain inefficient. Priorities have been driven by the imperative to link different 
parts of the country or provide regional access. ADB has assisted MOTC to introduce best 
practices through recently completed TA10 that aimed to help (i) set up highway information 
systems  and  a  database,  (ii)  introduce  prioritization  tools,  and  (iii)  prepare  road  sector 
intervention  plans.  In  recognition  of  the  need  of  a  new  approach  to  sector  planning  and 
management,  MOTC  was  reorganized  in  2007.  Its  current  organizational  structure  is  in 
Appendix  3.  Four  separate  agencies,  including  the  Bishkek–Torugart  Road  Corridor 
Management Department (BTRCMD), were set up to operate and maintain main international 
road corridors. Two more agencies are expected to be established in 2008. Institutional support 
will be needed to strengthen capacity of MOTC and help implement tasks outlined in RSDS, 
particularly  those  relating  to  institutional  reforms,  road  management,  road  safety,  and 
introduction of modern technologies for planning and monitoring.  
 
18.  Limited Institutional Capacity. Constrained institutional capacity in the transport sector 
limits the introduction of best practices on planning, management, operation, and maintenance. 
The sector’s financial management capacity is weak; and international accounting and auditing 
procedures have yet to be followed. Despite the growing need, the sector is losing experienced 
managerial and technical personnel because of low salaries and lack of incentives. No effort 
has  been  made  to  coordinate  with  the  academic  institutions  to  train  qualified  technical 
personnel. Neither is there a strategy to supply professionals to meet the demand of current 
sector needs.

c.  Accumulated Financing Shortfall 
19.  The severe fiscal constraints in the Kyrgyz Republic have limited budget allocations for 
improving and maintaining roads to only 20% of the required level. The Government relies 
heavily on external funding, which amounted to $350 million over the last 10 years. RSDS 
states that the Kyrgyz Republic would need over $1 billion to rehabilitate its 2,242 km of major 
road  corridors  and  $48  million  for  annual  maintenance  over  the  next  5  years  to  bring  its 
devastated  road  network  back  into  a  maintainable  condition.  This  is  a  challenge  to  the 
Government. The way forward is to raise sufficient revenues by introducing revenue-generating 
mechanisms and involve the private sector to efficiently utilize available funds. To address some 
of  the  above  issues,  the  Government  has  requested  ADB  assistance  to  develop  a 
comprehensive long-term transport sector master plan. The Project will contribute to reducing 
the shortfall in capital investment in the Kyrgyz Republic and will develop a transport sector 
master plan. 
 
2.  Government Strategies  
20.  Development of the transport sector is a high priority of the Government as reflected in 
its Country Development Strategy for 2007–2010. It calls for developing international road 
corridors  to  facilitate  regional  trade  and  transit  traffic,  as  well  as  establishing  legal  and 
regulatory frameworks to encourage private sector participation in transport. The Government’s 
policy  directives  also  require  developing  the  transport  sector  based  on  market-oriented 
principles to improve efficiency.  
 
21.  Substantial  investments,  as  mentioned  in  para.  19,  were  made  to  rehabilitate  the 
country’s major road corridors. Along with these investments, the Kyrgyz Republic has also 
made progress in reforming transport sector operations. It adopted the RSDS, increased road 
financing,  and  plans  to  outsource  and  eventually  privatize  road  maintenance  operations. 
Improvement  of  the  Bishkek–Torugart  road  is  a  priority  investment  project  included  in  the 
Government’s strategy. 
 
3.  ADB Strategy  
22.  ADB is the lead partner in developing the country’s transport sector. The Project is fully 
consistent  with  ADB’s  CAREC  Regional  Cooperation  Strategy  and  Program.11 The  Project 
supports two of the four strategic objectives identified in the regional cooperation strategy and 
program: (i) increasing trade and integration with large markets in South Asia, PRC, Iran, Turkey, 
and Russian Federation; and (ii) improving economic cooperation to reduce transport costs and 
facilitate trade and transit, allowing Central Asian countries to become integrated and use their 
location to their advantage. Development of the transport sector is also a priority area in the Joint 
Country Support Strategy for the Kyrgyz Republic (2007–2010).12 The Project will complement 
ADB-led investment and policy dialogue in the country and complete a key transport corridor 
connecting its capital Bishkek to Kashi in the PRC.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
50.  By  improving  the  Bishkek–Torugart  road,  the  Project  will  substantially  reduce  the 
existing obstruction to trade and will foster regional economic cooperation. The entire region will 
benefit from the Project, while the project area will gain through economic growth and increased 
access to markets and social services. Improving the project road will reduce transport costs, 
contribute  to  commercial  and  industrial  development,  develop  tourism,  and  generate 
employment opportunities. 
 
1.  Traffic Forecast 
51.  Traffic forecasts for the Project were based on the following three key assumptions: (i) 
political stability and strong macroeconomic performance in the Kyrgyz Republic, (ii) continued 
commitment of the governments of the Kyrgyz Republic and the PRC to regional cooperation, 
and  (iii)  continued  external  assistance  to  the  road  subsector  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The 
forecasts were made for the 2009–2032 period and are based on expected growth in gross 
domestic  product,  income  elasticities  of  demand,  and  analysis  of  regional  trade  patterns 
(Appendix 9). Passenger traffic volumes are expected to grow at an annual average rate of 
10%, and freight traffic volumes are expected to grow at annual average rate of 12%. After road 
improvement, additional traffic will be diverted to some sections of the project road from exiting 
diversions and parallel roads. It is assumed that diverted traffic will constitute about 30–40% of 
normal traffic. Generated passenger traffic has been estimated at 15% of normal traffic, and 
generated freight traffic at 20% of normal traffic.  
 
52.  International  traffic  is  minimal  at  present  but  it  is  expected  to  grow  rapidly  after 
improvement of the project road. Based on an analysis of trade patterns between the Kyrgyz 
Republic and the PRC, international generated traffic is projected to grow from the current 80 
trucks per day to over 200 trucks per day by 2015 (85% of the total traffic). Total international 
traffic is projected to reach 1,500 vehicles per day by 2032. Other international traffic may be 
diverted from rail or other modes of transport, or other CAREC transport corridors. Potential 
benefits related to such traffic are uncertain at this stage and therefore disregarded in this 
analysis.   
 
2.  Economic Analysis 
53.  The economic analysis entailed projecting costs and benefits for with- and without-
project scenarios in accordance with ADB guidelines.19 The difference between the with- and 
without-project  cost  and  benefits  streams  represents  the  net  benefits  of  the  Project.  The 
economic analysis covers 25 years (2009–2032), comprising 5 years of construction and 20 
years  of  operation.  The  least-cost  option  was  selected  among  mutually  exclusive  project 
alternatives and various pavement treatment options. Details of the economic analysis are in 
Appendix 9. 
 
54.  The major benefits of the Project are (i) reduced road user costs through savings in 
vehicle operating costs and travel and transit times; (ii) induced roadside industrial, commercial, 
and tourism development; and (iii) increased mobility and access to social services for local 
communities  along  the  road  corridor.  The  project  costs  include  the  resource  cost  of  road

improvement and maintenance throughout the project life, which were estimated in financial 
terms and factored by 0.8520 to convert them to economic terms. Both costs and benefits are 
expressed in US dollars at mid-2008 price levels. 
 
55.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the overall Project is 14.7%, and the net 
present value is about $37.8 million, using a 12% discount rate. Sensitivity analysis tested the 
effects of negative changes in key parameters determining project benefits and costs. The 
results of the sensitivity analysis show that the Project would maintain economic viability with an 
EIRR  of  12%  under  various  adverse  scenarios.  The  most  adverse  scenario  entails  the 
combined  effect  of  surging  oil  prices  and  therefore  reduced  traffic  demand  coupled  with 
sustained inflation for construction inputs, which reduces the EIRR to 9%. To mitigate this effect, 
due diligence for subsequent phases of improving the Bishkek–Torugart road will need to 
carefully  examine  prevailing  prices,  inflation  trends,  and  road  conditions  to  ensure  that 
improvement options are aligned with economic sustainability requirements. The Project is 
expected to help boost trade between the Kyrgyz Republic and the PRC. The total volume of 
bilateral trade is expected to grow from 0.5 million tons in 2007 to 3 million tons in 2015, of 
which the Kyrgyz Republic–PRC border at Torugart is expected to contribute more than half.  
 
B.  Social and Poverty Impacts  
56.  The Project is not a targeted poverty intervention, but it will have poverty reduction impact 
and  benefits  by  stimulating  economic  development.  The  results  of  the  social  and  poverty 
assessments undertaken are presented in the summary poverty reduction and social strategy in 
Appendix  10.  While  the  Project  aims  to  facilitate  regional  trade  and  thereby  benefit  major 
businesses  and  those  involved  in  trade  and  commerce,  it  will  also  significantly  benefit  rural 
communities and especially rural poor. Specifically, the Project will indirectly benefit 2.3 million 
people living along the project road, 51% of whom are women dominant in intra- and inter-oblast 
(province) trade and commercial activities in the Kyrgyz Republic. Two of the three oblasts through 
which the project road passes have poverty levels that are below the national average of 46%; 
extreme poverty in these two oblasts is almost double the national average of 13.5%.  
 
57.  The project road passes mostly through rural areas of the Kyrgyz Republic, where 
agriculture is the main source of income and poverty incidence is among the highest in the 
country.  Residents  considered  improvement  of  the  road  as  one  of  their  top  priorities  for 
development. Those to benefit most would be people whose livelihoods are directly linked to the 
road, such as truck owners and drivers, shuttles and/or taxi services, merchants, owners and 
employees of cafés, fuel stations, maintenance shops, and farmers. Increased labor and trade 
mobility in the area will lead to increased incomes and employment opportunities for the local 
communities. Overall, connectivity is seen as increasing transboundary transport and tourism 
development, thereby augmenting local employment and incomes. The immediate benefits of 
the Project are the opportunity for laborers in road construction works. 
 
58.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  in  the  early  stages  of  the  HIV/AIDS  epidemic.  However, 
HIV/AIDS  has  still  been  identified  as  a  potential  risk.  A  public  awareness  campaign  for 
HIV/AIDS prevention will be included as part of project management. The EA, with the help of 
project  supervision  consultants,  will  design  specific  links  with  national  and  donor-assisted 
HIV/AIDS prevention programs, and will monitor implementation. Specific provisions will be 
included in the bidding documents for civil works requiring contractors to conduct health and

C.  Social Safeguards  
59.  The Project classification for resettlement impact is category C. All civil works will take 
place  within  the  existing  right-of-way  or  on  unused  state-owned  land.  No  relocation  of 
households or acquisition of productive land is expected. If the Project needs new borrow pits or 
quarries, these are expected to be located on unused state-owned land.  
 
60.  The project classification for impact on indigenous people is category C. In 2005 the 
population in the project area consisted of 99% Kyrgyz and other nationalities including Uzbek, 
Uygurs, Russians, Tajiks, and Tatars. Although the cultures and languages of these groups 
differ, there are many similarities. They have lived in the same region for a long time and have 
been  integrated  in  the  same  economic  and  social  structure.  Moreover,  the  project  road 
alignment touches only the Kyrgyz settlements and none of them will be adversely affected. 
There are no groups with characteristics of indigenous people (as defined by ADB’s Policy on 
Indigenous Peoples [1998]) affected by the Project.  
 
D.  Environmental Impacts  
61.  The environmental classification for the Project is category B. The initial environmental 
examination (IEE) was carried out in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and 
Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines.21 Based  on  results  of  the  IEE,  the  Project  is  not 
expected  to  generate  significant  environmental  impacts,  provided  the  mitigation  measures 
outlined in the IEE and environmental management plan (EMP) are implemented appropriately. 
The summary IEE is in Appendix 11. The EMP as detailed in the IEE and outlined in summary 
IEE includes mitigation measures and a monitoring program for both the construction and 
operation phases of the Project.  
  
62.  The Government will ensure that the level of environmental impact from improvement of 
the project road will be kept to a minimum, especially in those areas of high ecological value. This 
will be achieved through effective monitoring and supervision of construction activities, as well as 
implementation of all  necessary environmental mitigation  measures.  All contracts will clearly 
identify the environmental responsibilities of all parties and the Government will enforce these 
contractual requirements. All works will be carried out in accordance with the environmental laws 
and  regulations  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  ADB’s  environmental  policies,  procedures  and 
guidelines, specifically ADB's Environment Policy. 
 
E.  Project Assumptions and Risks 
63.  The Project was designed with reasonable assumptions and taking into account the risks 
that  could  prevent  the  Project’s  intended  impact  and  outcome  from  fully  materializing.  Key 
assumptions are (i) continued political stability and strong economic performance in the Kyrgyz 
Republic; (ii) the commitments of the governments of the Kyrgyz Republic and the PRC to regional 
cooperation and to completing improvement of Bishkek–Torugart road corridor; (iii) continued 
external assistance to the road subsector in the Kyrgyz Republic; and (iv) implementation of the 
cross-border agreement between the Kyrgyz Republic, PRC, and Tajikistan with ADB assistance

A.  Road Infrastructure 
 
1.  The road network in the Kyrgyz Republic covers all seven oblasts (provinces), and 
provides  connections  to  remote  communities  and  links  to  neighboring  countries.  The  road 
network comprises 34,720 kilometers (km) of roads, 18,810 km of which are public roads and 
15,910 km of which are urban, rural, agricultural, industrial, and other roads. The road network 
of the Kyrgyz Republic carries about 95% of the country's passenger and freight traffic. The total 
length of international roads is 4,163 km, national roads total 5,678 km, and local roads total 
8,969 km; the length of paved public roads is 7,228 km, comprising 11 km of cement-concrete 
roads, 4,969 km of asphalt roads, and 2,248 km of bitumen treated gravel roads. The total 
length of gravel road is 9,961 km, and there is 1,621 km of unpaved roads.   
 
2.  About 18,800 km of roads (9,800 km of state roads and 9,000 km of local roads) are 
under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) (Table A2.1).

50% are gravel and less than 10% are earth roads. Since most of the roads were designed for 
higher  traffic  capacity  and  are  underutilized,  the  existing  basic  transport  infrastructure  is 
adequate for the level of economic activity likely to occur in the medium term. Consequently, the 
primary  concern  is  not  expansion  or  major  upgrading  of  the  transport  system,  but  proper 
maintenance  and  rehabilitation  to  preserve  the  existing  network.  Roads  at  all  levels  are 
deteriorating; over 60% now require periodic maintenance or rehabilitation.

principles,  they  contain  rigid  criteria  for  upgrading  road  capacity  that  are  based  on  traffic 
volumes and do not consider the level of services or economic viability. The inappropriateness 
of such standards for a market-based economy is widely recognized; they need updating to 
match the needs and economic resource base of the country.

momentum with continued strong economic growth in the country. The rapid increase in vehicle

D.  Financing and Maintenance 
 
10.  The Road Fund enacted in 1998 has never truly functioned. Taxes are collected in the 
name of the Road Fund, but are consolidated under the Government’s central budget of the 
Ministry of Finance. The Road Fund Council, with the responsibility to oversee the management 
of the Road Fund, was decreed in 2003, but it never met. RSDS suggests the need for clearer 
and  predictable  financing  mechanisms,  including  full  functionality  of  the  Road  Fund,  and 
revisions to the revenue structure and sources. 
 
11.  To implement the RSDS, the Government estimated that (i) investment of $490 million 
would be needed to complete the rehabilitation of the remaining two key regional corridors, i.e., 
the Bishkek–Torugart road and Osh–Isfana road; and (ii) annual maintenance funding of $48 
million would be required for all MOTC-administered roads. While funds for improvement of 
regional corridors will be sourced mainly from international financial institutions, financing road 
maintenance at the required level remains a challenge. However, the Government has made

E.  Road Safety 
 
17.  Recognizing  that  road  safety  is  critical,  the  Government  stressed  the  need  for 
improvement in this area in RSDS as one of the major tasks and set a target to reduce the 
current rate of accidents from 22 fatalities per 1,000 vehicles to 17 during 2008–2010. The 
Permanent Secretariat for Road Safety, established in 2004 under the Asian Development Bank 
assistance, has been actively working to revise existing road safety guidelines and prepare the 
National Road Safety Program, which is expected to be approved in late 2008. The Road Safety 
Secretariat has identified an alarming national problem of road accident injuries and property 
damage.  
 
18.  Increased motorization contributes to a higher number of accidents, with the fatality rate 
growing steadily. Analysis of accident data shows that speeding and reckless driving are the 
major factors contributing to high fatality rates. The poor road network condition is also a major 
contributor. Accident statics over the past 10 years are shown in Table A2.5.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The Project will indirectly benefit 2.26 million people living along the road, 51% of whom are women dominant in intra- and 
inter-oblast (province) trade and commercial activities in the Kyrgyz Republic. Two of the three oblasts through which the 
project road passes have poverty levels that are below the national average of 46%. Extreme poverty in these two oblasts is 
almost double the national average of 13.5%.  
 
The project road passes mostly through rural areas of the Kyrgyz Republic where agriculture is the main source of income 
and poverty incidence is among the highest in the country. Residents considered improvement of the road as one of their top 
priorities for development. Those to benefit most would be people whose livelihoods are linked to the road: truck owners and 
drivers, shuttles and/or taxi services, merchants, owners and employees of cafés, fuel stations, maintenance shops, and 
farmers. Increased labor and trade mobility in the area will lead to increased incomes and employment opportunities for the 
local communities. Overall, connectivity is seen as increasing transboundary transport and tourism development, thereby 
augmenting local employment and incomes. The immediate benefits of the Project are the opportunity for laborers in road 
construction works. 
 
Road improvement in the Kyrgyz Republic has special significance for women as they are extensively involved in trading for 
supporting their families. Hence, women are the major road users in the country. Improvement of the road will have positive 
impact on these women providing increased self-employment. The potential negative impacts on women as suspected are 
increased risks of HIV infection and trafficking. Opportunities for women will be explored for income and employment in 
construction activities with equal wages, and their increased self-employment in business and trade.

10.  Topography. The section is located within the mountain system of the Internal Tien-
Shan. The section begins near the Dolon Pass (altitude 3,030 m) at Km 280. From the Dolon 
Pass the right-of-way (ROW) descends to the Karaunkur–Ottuk Gorge and continues to the 
Middle Naryn Valley, where it passes through the eastern part of Naryn town (altitude 2,100 m) 
and crosses the Naryn River. A few kilometers further on, the section ascends to the Kyzyl Bel 
Pass (altitude 2,500 m) and Char Pass (2,600 m), and crosses them to enter the At-Bashi 
Valley. The section traverses the At-Bashi Valley parallel to the At-Bashi Ridge, until it reaches 
the western part of the ridge. It then turns south and ascends to the Ak Beit Pass (altitude 3284 
m), crosses the northern branch of the At-Bashi Ridge, and continues down to the Arpa Valley. 
The final point of the section is located passed the Ak Beit Pass in the Arpa Valley at Km 476. 
 
11.  Geological and Seismic Characteristics. Geologically, the section is located within the 
Middle Tien-Shan that is separated from the North Tien-Shan by so called “Nikolaev line”. The 
line (fault) crosses the section several kilometers to the south of the Dolon Pass. The whole 
section lies within the area where the probability of an earthquake is assessed as 8 , i.e., two

12.  Soils and Permafrost. The Project area comprises a number of soils that belong to 
soils of mountain slopes and soils of intermountain valleys: mountain meadow steppe sub-
alpine soil, mountain dark-chestnut soil, mountain light-chestnut soil, mountain  valley light-
chestnut  soil,  mountain  light-chestnut  soil,  mountain  valley  light-brown  soil,  and  mountain 
meadow steppe alpine soil. The top of the Dolon Pass (Km 282–Km 283) and the Ak Beit Pass 
(Km 464–Km 476) are located within island permafrost distribution areas. 
 
13.  Climate and Air Quality. The climate in the Internal Tien-Shan is continental with little rain, 
cool summers, and cold winters. Climatic conditions vary considerably with elevation. The average 
winter temperature ranges from –25°С to –45°С (the lowest may exceed –54°С), while in summer it 
varies from 20°С to 30°С. In winter frosts occur in all regions. Rain and snow usually fall in autumn, 
winter, and spring. Average yearly precipitation is 230–560 millimeters. The air quality is generally 
good, except on unsurfaced sections where dust generated from passing vehicles was observed. 
There are no ambient air quality monitoring stations in proximity to the section. 
 
14.  Hydrology. The alignment crosses the River Naryn, the largest in the Kyrgyz Republic, 
as well as two other major rivers, the At-Bashi and the On-Archa. On descent from the Dolon 
Pass it runs parallel to the Karaunkur and Ottuk rivers. High groundwater tables occur in Kara-
Suu and Ottuk villages. An initial visual assessment suggests that water quality is good. This 
appears to be confirmed by reports that the rivers support a healthy and diverse population of 
fish and macroinvertebrates. Chemical analysis and analysis of macrozoobenthos in major 
rivers  of  the  project  area  was  carried  out  as  part  of  the  environmental  assessment.  The 
chemical analysis of samples from the Naryn, At-Bashi, On-Archa, and Karaunkur rivers was

15.  Natural Hazards. Natural hazards related to the section include landslides, mudflows 
and seasonal flooding, rock falls, and avalanches. The section is susceptible to a massive 
landslide in the proximity of the Kyzyl-Bel Pass at Km 355–Km 356. The possibility of mudflow

16.  Noise and Vibration. The majority of the alignment runs through areas with no settlements, 
but only mountains, hills, and open steppe. Rare settlements through which the road corridor runs 
are Naryn town and the villages of Karaunkur, Ottuk, Kara-Suu, and Karabulung. Although no 
sensitive receptors such as schools and hospitals were noted near the ROW, noise and vibration 
are the serious concern to the communities that were raised repeatedly during public consultations. 
Dwellings are typically made of clay brick. For those located close to the roadside, noise and 
vibration from heavy trucks have the potential to significantly impact the houses and their occupants. 
Also, it was noted during the field investigations that the actual speed of vehicles passing through 
the settlements rarely matches the speed limits. This contributes to safety and noise problems.

into the detailed design by surveying at the pre-project stage the current condition of permafrost

exception of a graveyard (Km 314) located close to the alignment that may be affected by vibration.  
 
61.  Mitigation. No mitigation related to known cultural resources is warranted. Contract 
provisions  are  recommended  to  ensure  that  construction  works  are  suspended,  local 
administration and state organizations on cultural heritage are informed, and all necessary 
measures to protect cultural resources are taken in the event of unexpected discoveries. The 
fencing of the graveyard located at Km 314 should be strengthened. 
 
E.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Management and Monitoring Plan 
 
62.  Legal and Institutional Framework. According to the Law on Environmental Expertise, any 
project  activities  should  be  preceded  by  preparation  and  submission  of  OVOS  (the  Russian 
acronym for “assessment of environmental impacts”), and its approval by Ecological Expertise 
(State Environmental Review). The OVOS documentation should include endorsements from local 
administration, sanitary control bodies, Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources and Processing 
Industry and other organizations, depending on environmental attributes affected by the Project. 
 
63.  Institutional Requirements. The Investment Projects Implementation Department (IPID) 
will be responsible for ensuring that environmental procedures are incorporated in each stage of the

Appendix 11  57 
work—such as document tender and contract preparation, bid reviews and awards, and supervision 
of preconstruction baseline monitoring—as an integral part of construction supervision.  
 
64.  IPID will be responsible for overall contract administration and day-to-day project supervision 
including environmental management. An environment and/or social officer will be appointed within 
IPID to be responsible for ensuring the environmental management plan, including monitoring 
requirements, are implemented effectively. The construction supervision consultant will assist IPID 
in its responsibilities, including instrumental environmental monitoring of the Project.  
 
65.  Environmental Monitoring Program. The environmental monitoring program includes 
routine site inspections and reporting related to soil and erosion control; embankment and 
erosion protection; borrow-pit restoration; noise, vibration, air, and water quality monitoring 
(including baseline and routine periodic water quality monitoring); and terrestrial and/or river 
ecosystem health monitoring. Specific monitoring provisions include:  
(i)  Water  quality.  Instrumented  baseline  and  routine  periodic  water  quality 
monitoring. It will be complemented with routine monitoring of water quality by 
macrozoobenthos (once a year for 2 years). 
(ii)  Air quality. Instrumented baseline and routine periodic air quality monitoring.  
(iii)  Noise. Instrumented baseline and routine periodic air quality monitoring.  
(iv)  Ecosystem degradation. Routine roadside ecosystem monitoring by indicator 
bird species. 
(v)  Land use-related impacts. Monitoring of quarry activities, siting of construction 
camps and related facilities, and siting of asphalt plants.  
 
66.  Environmental Management Plan. The summary plan is in Table A11.3. 
  
F.  Public Consultations 
 
67.  A  number  of  public  consultations  with  experts,  local  administrations,  nongovernment 
organizations, and the general public were held in May–June 2008. Informal consultations with the 
local population in Karaunkur, Ottuk, Kara-Suu, and Karabulung villages, and with representatives of 
nongovernment  organizations  were  held  in  Bishkek.  A  stakeholder  workshop  for  local 
administrations of Naryn and At-Bashi rayons was conducted on 16 June 2008. Also, consultations 
with experts from the Ministry of Emergencies, Ministry of Transport and Communications, and 
Academy  of  Sciences  were  held.  The  comments  from  previous  large  stakeholder  workshops 
conducted in Naryn and Bishkek in 2006 were used to assess the actuality of the problem. 
 
68.  A summary of the opinions of the public consultations is as follows: 
(i)  The local population supports the upgrading of the road corridor provided that it 
will bring more socioeconomic benefits to the local population. 
(ii)  Feeder roads were proposed by locals to be included in the Project, specifically two 
roads connecting rayon center At-Bashi and EM-07, and the main street in Naryn 
that is a part of the road linking Ak-Talaa rayon and Tash-Bashat village. 
(iii)  Due  to  safety  and  noise  and/or  vibration  issues,  it  was  proposed  that 
consideration be given to bypasses of Ottuk, Kara-Suu, and Karabulung villages. 
(iv)  Noise and vibration issues were the major concern in Ottuk, Kara-Suu, and 
Karabulung villages and Naryn town. The recent letter from the people of Ottuk to 
MOTC repeatedly raised these issues.  
(v)  Local people should be involved in the road construction.

G.  Findings and Recommendations 
 
69.  The findings of the IEE are as follows: 
(i)  Construction activities under the Project will be largely of a rehabilitation nature 
within the previously disturbed road corridor and no significant environmental 
impacts are anticipated. 
(ii)  The Km 355–Km 357 (Kyzyl–Bel Pass) section is a landslide-prone area for which 
at least three alternatives were proposed: existing route, bypass, and viaduct. On 
the basis of information available, the Design Institute proposes the existing route 
in combination with geotechnical measures as the optimal alternative.  
(iii)  The study of ecosystems health conducted in the frame of this IEE showed that 
there are ecosystems in the Project area that are more sensitive to environmental 
impacts, specifically: mid-mountain flood-plain and meadow ecosystems located in 
the Karaunkur–Ottuk gorge, and sub-alpine ecosystems (Dolon and Ak Beit passes). 
(iv)  According to the local people from Karaunkur, Ottuk, Kara-Suu, and Karabulung 
villages living in proximity to the road, noise and vibration have an impact on their 
houses.  However,  visual  examination  showed  that  the  houses  are  located 
outside the ROW, and the major problem is probably related to overloaded trucks 
and their noncompliance with the 30 km/hr speed limit.  
(v)  The  examination  of  baseline  water  quality  in  rivers  of  the  project  area  by 
chemical analysis and bioindicators survey undertaken within the frame of the 
IEE showed that water quality is good. 
 
70.  The following recommendations are proposed based on the findings of the IEE: 
(i)  Environmental provisions in contract. Specific environmental provisions are 
recommended for inclusion in contract documents including provisions related 
but not limited to: (a) erosion control and air and water quality control; (b) location 
of asphalt plants, construction camps, and other facilities (not in environmentally 
sensitive areas indicated above); (c) borrow-pit restoration; (d) quarry operations; 
(e) safety provisions; (f) baseline and routine monitoring of air quality, water 
quality, noise, and ecosystem health; and (g) community relations. 
(ii)  Environmental monitoring. Baseline noise, vibration and air quality monitoring 
is recommended at the preconstruction stage in settlements along the road. 
(iii)  Capacity  building  for  environmental  management. A training program for 
selected  staff  and  addressed  to  the  goals  and  techniques  of  environmental 
management activities in road projects is recommended. 
(iv)  Recommended complementary projects. A training program to ensure that 
local businesses and population will be able to use all the benefits provided by 
being  adjacent  to  the  international  road  corridor  is  recommended.  A 
complementary  project  to  increase  attractiveness  of  the  Salkyn-Tor  State 
National Park for ecotourists is recommended.  
 
H.  Conclusions 
 
71.  The  Project  will  have  significant  social  benefits  and,  if  the  prescribed  mitigation  and 
management measures are fully implemented, the Project is unlikely to have major adverse 
environmental impacts. An environmental monitoring plan has been prepared and responsibilities 
for implementation assigned. A budget has been allocated for environmental management and 
monitoring. A full environmental impact assessment under ADB guidelines is not required.
